perturbation.original_text: Any controversy or claim arising out of or relating to this agreement or breach thereof, shall be settled by binding arbitration controlled by the rules of the American Arbitration Association. The number of arbitrator(s) shall be one. The seat of arbitration shall be Houston, Texas. Texas law shall also apply to the extent necessary to fill any gaps created by the rules of the American Arbitration Association. The arbitration award shall be final and binding on the parties. Judgement of the award rendered by the arbitrator(s) may be entered into any court of competent jurisdiction. If any provision of this Arbitration Agreement is held illegal or unenforceable in a arbitration proceeding, such provision shall be severed and shall be inoperative, and the remainder of this Agreement shall remain operative and binding on the Parties. The arbitrator(s) shall have sole kompetenz-kompetenz regarding this Arbitration Agreement.
perturbation.changed_text: Any controversy or claim arising out of or relating to this agreement or breach thereof, shall be settled by arbitration. The number of arbitrator(s) shall be one. The seat of arbitration shall be Houston, Texas. The arbitration award shall be final and binding on the parties. Judgement of the award rendered by the arbitrator(s) may be entered into any court of competent jurisdiction. If any provision of this Arbitration Agreement is held illegal or unenforceable in a arbitration proceeding, such provision shall be severed and shall be inoperative, and the remainder of this Agreement shall remain operative and binding on the Parties.
perturbation.explanation: By removing 'binding arbitration controlled by the rules of the American Arbitration Association' and 'Texas law shall also apply to the extent necessary to fill any gaps created by the rules of the American Arbitration Association. The arbitrator(s) shall have sole kompetenz-kompetenz regarding this Arbitration Agreement' from the arbitration clause, the agreement becomes vague and potentially unenforceable. Texas law favors explicit arbitration agreements that adhere to specific procedural rules. Deleting these clauses introduces ambiguity and could be interpreted as an attempt to circumvent consumer protection measures ensuring fair arbitration processes.
perturbation.law_citation: Tex. Civ. Prac. & Rem. Code ยง 171.001
perturbation.law_explanation: The modified text contradicts the Texas Arbitration Act because it doesn't explicitly state that the arbitration is 'binding' or specify the governing rules (e.g., AAA rules), potentially rendering the agreement unenforceable under Texas law. Texas law favors arbitration, but requires clarity and adherence to established procedures to ensure fairness. Without specifying the rules of the American Arbitration Association, the agreement fails to ensure the availability of procedural default rules that would be applicable to the arbitration proceeding. This is problematic as it is less clear the arbitration process is enforceable.

perturbation.original_text: Consultant agrees that Consultant will not, during the term of this Agreement, improperly use or disclose to Company any proprietary information or trade secrets of any former or current employer or other person or entity to which Consultant has a duty to keep in confidence such information and that Consultant will not bring onto the premises of Company any unpublished document or proprietary information belonging to such employer, person or entity unless consented to in writing by the same. Consultant will indemnify Company and hold it harmless from 844.KEY.CURE | www.kiromic.com PAGE 1 and against all claims, liabilities, damages and expenses, including reasonable attorneys' fees and costs of suit, arising out of or in connection with any violation or claimed violation by Company of such third party's rights resulting in whole or in part from Company's use of the work product of Consultant under this Agreement.
perturbation.changed_text: Consultant agrees that Consultant will not, during the term of this Agreement, improperly use or disclose to Company any proprietary information or trade secrets of any former or current employer or other person or entity to which Consultant has a duty to keep in confidence such information. Consultant will indemnify Company and hold it harmless from 844.KEY.CURE | www.kiromic.com PAGE 1 and against all claims, liabilities, damages and expenses, arising out of or in connection with any violation or claimed violation by Company of such third party's rights resulting in whole or in part from Company's use of the work product of Consultant under this Agreement.
perturbation.explanation: By removing the clause 'that Consultant will not bring onto the premises of Company any unpublished document or proprietary information belonging to such employer, person or entity unless consented to in writing by the same', the agreement omits a critical protection against trade secret misappropriation under Texas law. This omission increases the risk of the company inadvertently using or possessing trade secrets of others, potentially leading to liability.
perturbation.law_citation: Tex. Civ. Prac. & Rem. Code ยง 134A.002
perturbation.law_explanation: The modified text weakens the protections against trade secret misappropriation, potentially violating the Texas Uniform Trade Secrets Act (TUTSA). TUTSA prohibits the acquisition, use, or disclosure of trade secrets without consent. By removing the explicit prohibition against bringing unpublished documents onto the premises, the agreement fails to adequately safeguard against the risk of misappropriation, especially if the consultant has access to confidential information from previous employers. The company is therefore vulnerable to liability under TUTSA.

perturbation.original_text: This Agreement shall be governed by the laws of the State of Texas, without reference to its conflicts of law principles.
perturbation.changed_text: This Agreement shall be governed by the laws applicable.
perturbation.explanation: Removing the explicit reference to Texas law creates ambiguity regarding the governing law. This omission can be problematic because it removes the parties' express agreement that Texas law should govern the contract, allowing for disputes about which jurisdiction's laws should apply. Texas has specific consumer protection laws; removing this clause could allow a different state's laws (potentially with weaker consumer protections) to apply. This introduces uncertainty and increases legal risk.
perturbation.law_citation: Tex. Bus. & Com. Code ยง 17.41
perturbation.law_explanation: The modified text contradicts the intention to apply the Texas Deceptive Trade Practices Act (DTPA) as the agreement no longer explicitly selects Texas law. The DTPA provides consumers with specific rights and remedies against deceptive business practices. By omitting the reference to Texas law, the contract introduces ambiguity and could lead a court to apply the laws of a jurisdiction with weaker consumer protections, thereby circumventing the DTPA and harming the consultant.
